I just got done eating a Monster Cheeseburger from Jack in the Box, and I feel great. Infact, I have had two this week, and it doesn't bother me one bit. That is, until I look in the mirror. Yikes, I really need to cut twenty pounds off of my body, I think, as I walk back to my desk. But I feel fine. I feel good. And then I begin to think about me as a little girl, about being the fat kid no one liked, and I try to pinpoint it to one moment where it was decided by the world that I was fat. And now I remember. I was five years old, and it was circus day in my Day Care. It was in Montana, my parents were still married, and still happy (kinda). Yvonne, I think her name was, got to be the tight rope walker. She wore a lovely white frilly dress and ballet shoes and got to hold a magic wand. There were tigers and a ringmaster, and it was supposed to be fun. Until they told me I had to be the fat lady. I cried for a long time and I remember my mom trying to make the best of it by getting me a pretty red grown up dress and cutting it so it was short enough for me to wear. She found a lovely red hat to match and gave me long dangly earrings and rings to cover my fingers. But I was still upset when it came time to play, the counselers decided to just call me the pretty lady instead of the fat lady. I remember walking out into the clearing of people and, though I smiled and waved about, I felt to stupid, so ugly, so fat. And I was five years old. That moment changed it all for me. And perhaps my parent's divorce helped me to hide away in double chocolate ice cream cones and melted cheese, but when I think of the moment that really defined me as a fat girl, a fat person, it is the day my Day Care Center, run by adults, chose to make me the fat lady in their pretend game. Adults, who, now, wouldn't dare give that title to anyone, becuase it might hurt their feelings, didn't even think twice about the fact that I was so upset by being called something that everyone knows is a negative. No one ever says "wow, George, he's such a nice guy, He's so fat and I really like that about him". 

I have come to terms with the fact that I will never be a size 6. I think the smallest I have ever been was an 8 as an adult. I am larger now, probably somewhere between a 12 and 14, and there are days when I just want to run to a plastic surgeon or run fifty miles in hopes of getting the old "me" back. But then I remember, this is the me that I have always been, this is the me who has danced, who has camped, who has hiked and biked and has been deeply loved by so many. I've had passionate moments where I didn't once think of myself as anything other than devilishly sexy. This is the body I was given, and even though it's not a size 6, it's still one hell of a great body to have. I might stil be the fat lady, but my heart is fat to, and at least, at least, there is more of me to love!

8:39 am. Monday, January 1st. I'm waiting for the new year to begin happily, but it won't. To be honest, this new year has really sucked so far compared to last year. 8:40 am. I wonder if I should have a bath. I didn't drink last night but I feel dirty. I cna't find my keyds to get out of this place. I spent twenty minutes looking for them but to no avail. Wicket is fine - albeit a little cold. He has no hair now and it's in the forties outside. I wish it were snowing. I wish I had a river I could skate away on. I think Jonit Mitchell wrote that song after a night like last night, when everything went from lovely to terrible in less than tweny minutes. I bet she woke up alone like me and didn't know what to say about it, so she just picked up her guitar and wrote a song. I wish I could play guitar. 8:43 am the day will not move along. I have no idea where my keys are - escape is futile. I just want to be away from here, from this place of sadness and denial. It's a never ending story, right? Nothing ever ends, not really. 8:44 am. I shouldn't feel so bad. Some people go through their entire lives not having experienced the love that I have. I am stronger than I give myself credit for. I will be fine. I will not have fantasies about dying in this apartment, only to be discovered by wild boars. Bridget Jones wouldn't cry over something so silly as this, why should I? I wasn't that good in bed, anyway. Yes, that's it, let's be angry about it rather than depressed. 8:47. I should take a bath. It's cold in here and water is warm. water is warm. And my blood is cold, this world is cold, my poor dog is cold. On the edge of insanity, the view is lovely.

I am now, officially, 25 years old. While these seems to me to be kinda the last BIG birthday for a while, I am a bit bewildered as to how I got here. I remember being 16, dancing like a crazy person in the little house at my Dad and Patti's, eating barbeque from Rudy's and ice cream double chocolate cake. I remember getting the first Matchbox Twenty CD and how the first chords told me it was going to be my soundtrack for a while. I remember Singing to Eddie and everyone else in the room, and how it should have been clear to me that he liked me even then. 

Ah, but then I also remember my 21st birthday, held at the club house of my first apartment with Ben. Big John had made an appearance - and gave me my very first shot of tequila. Allison even was there, with Craigers and all the trimmings. There was no dancing, but I remember it being a pretty fantastic time. 

And I remember the ones in between then and now, some at club houses, some at the indoor pool in Billings. I even remember one (I think it was my 5th) at a farm in Montana. I got to milk a cow and drive a hay bale filled truck. 

What puzzles me most, however, is how I got to this birthday. I mean, it's been an interesting year. Let's Recap for the home audiance:

1) Last year, I was married to a guy named Ben. We were almost debt free, and while everything seemed ok on the outside, I was miserable in a lot of ways. Where is he now?  I hear he's still going to school and living with his chick - who he had been seeing the last few months of our marriage. I think he's a lot happier now, and I know I am. So that's a big step in the right direction.

2) I lived with three men: Ben, Kenneth, and Steve. Kenneth and Steve were like my family brothers who loved to watch me in short skirts. A little perverse, yes, but they were my close friends, and I trusted them. Where are they now? After Ben and I explained we were going to be moving closer to Houston, they moved out and left us with a house full of needed repairs and two months left of rent to pay. I haven't spoken to them since the day I left Ben for good. And while I am still pretty crushed by their actions, I miss the way they made me laugh. I live in an apartment now, although I am probably going to move again soon to something bigger.

3) I was not a mommy last year. This year, I am proud to be a mom to an adorable ball of furr and poopie named Wicket. He's my pride and joy - a Christmas gift from Ben (although, I ended up paying for it...go figure). He's doing well, trying to be good but sometimes failing. Robert and I are taking care to train him well. 

4) Oh yeah...I didn't have a soulmate last year. Or I did, but I didn't know who he was. But I do now :) His name is Robert and he's amazing. We started seeing each other in April and havent stopped since. And it's funny, because I am completely comfortable with him in a way I have never been before.  He is so good to me. And he's throwing me my 25th birthday party - can you believe it, someone is throwing ME a party instead of me throwing one myself? Tee hee! I just love him!

These are the changes, just to name a few. And they are vast. My life is completely different. And I love it. But again, I wonder how I got here, and how I got to the place where I am 5 years away from 30. I never thought I would get there! Never! They tell you that you will, and then they tell you that you will not believe it, but they are right! Them! Those adults! And now, I am one of THEM! AHHhh!

This year, I am going to be singing at a Karaoke Bar all night long and drinking rather heavily with friends. And I'm not going to worry about the past, or even about my future really. I think that this past year has shown me how fragile life can be, and how things change in an instant, and that there are no gurantees. But there is LOVE, and with that, there is no limit to what can be done in life. 

Love, and chocolate. 

I love you all - thank you for making my 25 years an amazing jouney. 

Love, your angel,

Michaela

And it's lovely! Well, it's raining and foggy out, but it's in the low 80's, which makes me and my warm-natured self pretty darn excited! Let's see, I should update on a few things.... 

I am no longer eating cheese. I am trying to go one full week without my favorite ingredient, and so far, it's not been a problem. I am on hour 14.5 and doing good. I have a feeling that it will be a long, hard road, however, when I get the craving. Luckily, this is only for a week. 

I spent the weekend in Corpus with Robert. We walked along the beach and had a blast just doing nothing. And there is a great place there that serves the most wonderful Chocolate Cake - it's called the Black Diamond. We ate their seafood, which we didn't like much, but their cake is AWESOME. We brought back 2 slices! Yummy! 

I haven't been dancing in two weeks and I miss it lots. This weekend we are going to ren fest with Wilber and some friends so I am excited about that - it's a tradition that Wilber and I have some funnel cake together, and that's no cheese, so I'm happy! I love Ren fest - it's a really nice time and I always get to dress up in something fun. 

I am very excited about my birthday party this year. It's going to be huge - and I'm letting Robert handle everything. And that's a big step for me, usually I handle anything that important to me, because I know I will not screw it up. And I never minded - could you have imagined if Ben had tried to plan a party? We would have gothic dyke strippers and magic cards with sides of milk and cheetoes. Anyway, it's a very big step for me to let someone else handle all the details - it's a lot of trust that I have never placed in anyone. And, oddly enough, it doesn't feel bad. I have a feeling it's going to be even better than if I had planned it myself. 

I saw The Departed last night - great, great film. It was so nice to not be dissapointed by a movie for once. Then I went home and crashed - it was a three hour long film, but it was excellent. I loved Leonardo DiCaprio, I really think he's talented. And Matt Damon plays a good/bad guy pretty well. Of course, the cake topper was Jack Nicholson, who will probably again get nominated - or even will take home the award for best actor by the academy. 

Quincy just sent me an email - he wants to get together this weekend - I am SOO excited! I haven't seen him in five years. I bet he is doing wonderfully. He was in engineering school and he's a freakin genius, so I bet he's doing well. It's been such a long time that I wonder how we will get along now, after so much time had gone by. I mean, we dabated a lot, especially about love. But now that we are older, I wonder what we will talk about other than what's been going on in our lives. I hope he found love. I hope his family is well. It's so nice that he remembered me-I worry sometimes that when I die, I will be forgotten forever and that my actions or words will not have done any good to anyone. 

I just had a very interesting conversation with an old friend I used to know well. I don't know them so well now, and I am not really worried about it. For some reason, I do not feel like I have failed them, even though I had to let them go. It was a hard thing to do, but it was for the better, and they seem much happier on their own, without their crutch, without an angel. watching over them. Perhaps there are people who thrive when no one watches over them. Or maybe I'm just silly. I don't really feel like anyone has watched out for me in that way, and I think I turned out ok. When you are a mess, and I have often been a mess, you don't want the world to know. And this person was a mess for a long time. But they feel like, for the first time, maybe things are coming together for them, and it has to do a lot with Chance and Faith and Hope. And I'm happier for them than I thought I would be. Because I have my own miracles to look at everyday. I have love that I don't think many people have ever experienced, and I let it in and it washes me clean of my fears and failings. 

My life is brilliant.

I am SOOO happy today! I have finally finished with the final proceedings of my divorce, and I am once again SINGLE!!!! Yay!!!! ::does the happy Single girl dance::::

It truly is a freeing experience. I have my name back, I have my life to myself again, and I never have to deal with Ben ever, ever again. It wasn't as bad as it could have been, but I am grateful it's over and that I can live my life in peace. Thank you GOD!

So, um...yeah, I'm gonna celebrate today by drinking lots and eating lots and having lots of fun with my single self! Tee hee! And the newest song by Anna Nalick keeps running in my head...

Me. A bottle of wine. Lots and lots of prayers for my friends and family. I'm falling, I'm floating, I'm so sorry for all the damage I have done to this world. I didn't mean it. I want this song played at my funeral. I want a lavender coffin there. I want to be remembered the way Jason remembers - only the stuff that's important. And I hope it's enough. I hope it's enough. I wish everyone was loved tonight. I wish they knew that they were loved. Being alone is such a sad, sad place. Everyone is forgiven now - the world begins again. Ah, yes, my love, my life will begin again.

I love you all.

I am having some issues with my emails. I love emails. I think it's great people remember to add me to their list of friends when they want to send crap out. However, lately I have been riddled with emails focusing on sending more of my friends crap out to my friends, and so on. Do I really think that by sending this email to everyone I know that a check for a million dollors will come in the mail? Do I really think God will be offended if I do not send "I'm a Christian and you're going to hell" out to everyone I know? I have no problem sending things along that are original or halarious, but the fift stroy of the man who stood up to god and some peice of chalk NOT breaking when it hit the ground is JUST SO OLD. I think God wants better material.

This week was long. I hurt my wrist so I haven't been typing much, forgive me for not updating my journal more often. I have re-emerged amongst many of my friends lives, just in time to feel guilty about being away from them. I saw Katia and Wilber this week, which was nice. I am seeing more of Tricia and Jim, which is always a good thing. And Robert, I am seeing a lot of him as well. I should call Tim soon - I miss him lots. 

Let's see, what else is going on. Just hanging on for the next big thing to come around - which it will, it's only a matter of time. As soon as I turn my head, I will miss the giant boulder headed my way. It's an inevitability. 

I am reading more of the short stories that Tim gave me from the author of the ice storm. I like his style, although I cannot be tired or I will lose my concentration and fall asleep. It's very left brained, stream of conscience, which I think is very hard to write in. I think I tried to do it once and failed miserably. 

I got the dates for Harvest Moon Ball - Sept 16th. Yes, that would be the same weekend as Showdown, so no one with any national notoriety will be at the ball, but Byron and Matt and Wilber will be there, so it will be perfect for me.

I dreamed about lindyfest last night. Matt and Byron were there, and I was dancing to some song that I cannot remember now. It was so vivid in my mind, I remember singing it when I woke up. But now it's just out of my head. Anyway, I was there with all my boys, and some strange man trying to get my attention. I even saw Jason there, but that was unpleasant. I think he made me cry. 

I saw a boy in the book store on Monday. I was there waiting to go to the HSDS board meeting (a meeting that was only half way finished after two hours), reading In Cold Blood by Truman Capote. I was reading the first chapter and noticed him sitting to my left, writing tiny tiny letters in a spiral notebook. I also noticed that his day planner was open and that each page had been completely covered with blue ink, with tiny blue letters. It was fascinating, although it did remind me a bit too much of Seven. He would sit and look around for a while, and then carefully write a few lines, and start all over again. I tried not to make eye contact, but he was lovely to watch. Very beach boy looking, with light blue eyes (not like Byrons - they were very empty) and sandy brown hair, cut short as if a surfer. His hands were regular looking, tanned, short nails, not bitten. I will never see him again but I wonder what he wrote on those pages, if maybe he was writing about this chubby girl to his right that was reading a Capote novel and stealing glances at him.

Here I am - at my parents house just to the left of the middle of nowhere. I arrived yesterday - later than I had originally hoped, but had soem trouble getting out of bed. The drive over was rather uneventfull - lots of clouds but very little rain and Wicket was an angel. I really think he knows that he's going to see his grandparents, and that he will eat better this weekend than he has since the last time we visited. 

It was a quiet day - we didn't leave the house. I promptly changed into my jammies and lazed around for the afternoon, catching glimpes of my parents watching the humming birds, playing with their cats, watching Wicket get chased around by a toy poodle named Roxy (who is visiting my parents for a few days). I eventually found myself upstairs sleeping until 8, and then Patti started on the best dinner in the world. She does that - she has this amazing shrimp and mushroom pasta served over linguini that she makes every time I come to visit. And this time, it was fabulous! My dad even said it was the greatest pasta she'd ever made - and that's pretty awesome. We had the wine that Robert got for them, and although my dad said it was a younger wine than he'd like, he drank a glass or two. Then Patti served us chilled jello with a whipped cream topping and we had some of Dad's famous coffee. Patti went off to bed and Daddy and I watched The Dance (a 1997 reunion concert of fleetwood mac - the greatest concert of all time, in my humble opinion). We figured out a way to record an mp3 from the dvd, so now I can have my two favorite songs on my IPOD - super nifty! 

I was exhausted by the time I reached my bed - but had the strangest dream. I dreamed a friend of mine, named Leon, told me how he had been in love with me for a long, long time. It was really strange because, like most people, I don't know how to react when something like that presents itself. So it was an awkward dream, one I was glad to awake from. And I awoke to a call from Robert letting me know he was about to board his flight. We talked for a few minutes and discovered that on planes, we both will ONLY drink Ginger ale. I would say that this would surprise me - the fact that we do something so quirky exactly the same - but it's happened so many times it seems like old news. 

I awoke this morning to a familiar scene - Patti at her computer, my dad smoking a cigar on the porch, my coffee still warm and waiting for me in the kitchen with my name on a card, covering the cup. Of course, it was perfect. Dad made a fully fantastic breakfast - typical fair for when I'm visiting - Sourdough bread (my dad's burnt) eggs, bacon, and hashbrowns. It looks like we will be going "into town" today to do some shopping and maybe play some pool. I am excited. 

I should go get ready. Patti takes an hour in the shower and she's just started, so I have some time. But I need to figure out what to wear and maybe read a bit - just to complete the feeling of luxury :)

So how does one go from being completely happy and wanting nothing more than to love out your days just the way things are to completey doubting yourself and everything around you? How does that happen within a matter of days, and for no reason? I think sometimes that I cannot just blame these times on being a woman. Sometimes I think I am just crazy. 

I worked yesterday, I came home and vegged. I worked out for half an hour and watched the rest of Willy Wonka and cried. I just love that movie - it's so delicious. 

And last night, I didn't want to talk to anyone. I just wanted to be alone to these awful thoughts in my head that resounded with perpetual dome and self doubt. Very strange. And then this morning, I woke up to warm amber and it was good again. I wasn't so bothered by my own mistakes. I can't beat myself up for things I have no control over.

It really reminds me of everything that has transpired the past couple months, and that feeling you get everynow and then of being overwhelmed. It's an amazing song and I remember hearing it in the car with Robert and telling him it was going to change lives.

I am a totally bad person for not keeping up with my journal, but things have been super crazy here. There is so much to say, to catch up on, I don't know where to begin.

Let's see. I'm not yet divorced, although I was gonna be two weeks ago. Things are getting rather ugly. Now I am accused of commiting adultary, which is interesting because I don't know how you can prove something that never (let me repeat, NEVER) happened. And I would also like to point out that I was not the one on racy websites looking to hook up with someone even back in September. Crazy stuff, I am telling you. I just want that all to be over and to have my name back.

Work is going well. I am pretty busy most days now, running around with five different hats trying to please everyone. The girls are doing alright - Laura just got back from a cruise and had a great time. 

Dancing is alright. I'm not teaching with Brian anymore, since it's his last summer before leaving for college (tear!) and he wanted to just hang out and dance. However, Robert is taking privates from him, so we still get to teach a bit. I haven't done much other than going to dance on Sundays, which only takes about an hour now to dance with everyone since it's the summer. 

Wilber just got an aquarium - he's wanted one for a long, long time, so it's a big deal. Things were kinda distant for a while, but everything is back to normal, although I don't see him as much anymore. 

My dad and Patti came down to visit for a weekend - that was pretty fun. I took them to the galleria and they went to see me dance. Of course, Ben showed up, so that was kind of awkward. But neither one said anything to each other, so that was nice. 

You know, the thing about ending a marriage is this - you never quiet get back to being friends. I mean, even in the most amicable ending of marriages, there is always that underlying tension and hurt and anger. It was sad because I spend a long time being upset about it, many nights not doing anything but praying that I was making the right choice, and all the while hoping that somewhere down the line, I would see Ben and the melody and we would just kinda exist without him hating me or me wishing he would grow up. My mother and I talked Sunday on my drive home, and I heard the most wonderful things. She told me about her and my father before it all went to hell. About how they would dance in the living room after my brother and I had gone to bed - about how he got down on one knee and had some earings to give her instead of a ring - about how when they got married, he said he was sorry for taking too long to sweep her off her feet. And my mother, MY MOTHER, the one who always is weary of men and their sweet promises and kisses, opened up like never before and gave me the best advise - when you fall in love like that, hold on to it for dear life and try not to lose it. And when she described it to me - "it was like being in heaven everyday of your life, you wake up everyday with the most wonderful person you know sleeping next to you" and I thought - wow, I wonder what that's like. There was no doubt, or worries, no fear. It was so simple, nothing extravegant, and it was just like in the movies. It was just like in the movies - thank you God. Thank You. 

I'm in heaven. Heaven!

A word about my love for the amazing Joni Mitchell. It's not just enough to say she rocks the freakin house, because most of my friends ::glances at Ben:: thinks that she sounds like a dying cat. And I have to admit, even growing up I didn't like much of her stuff. But now, now I cannot get enough of her anti-war, free love banter that makes me feel more like a person than most music I hear today. So I feel I should explain myself so that anyone who might be interesting in taking me down peice by peice can have adequate aim.

I love Joni's songs because I think she's screwed up somewhere in the neighborhood of where I am also screwed up. She always had a man on her shoulder, always wrote about the ones she loved and lost because she was a fool or they didn't want her. Sound familiar to anyone in this room? Well it should. I don't write songs, I write live journals. It's because I have tiny hands and cannot make the same chords Joni can. She could reach the most amazing chords, not many (none that I recall, actually) can make her songs the way she does. 

I love the way she ages into wiseness, how her newest version of "Both sides now" is so perfectly worn and honest, how her voice is cracked and weathered and still beautiful. She's a poet and musician and she helps me make it one rainy nights or grey monday's when I'm falling away into someone I don't want to become. And she's happy too. Her happiest songs have made other singers famous and rich - it was her, mind you, that penned "Big Yellow Taxi" - not Amy Grant (BLAH!!) or The Counting Crows (they did a much more realistic job). It was her who wrote the Circle Game, who had the words to woodstock before Eva Cassidy. It was her who most of the great contemporary artists (Shawn Colvin, Annie Lennox, Elton John, James Taylor, even Carly Simon) have credited with being the greatest most unknown artist there ever was. Do you know her ONLY chart topping song she did herself was "Help me"? And that was crap compared to so many other ballads. CRAP, I tell you!

It was my 24th birthday party and I was playing songs from my IPOD, and a song by Joni Mitchell came on, and I immediately went to change it. And then my friend Jason tried to stop me, saying, "but you love Joni Mitchell" and I smiled tightly and nodded, saying "but Ben doesn't like her". And he just shook his head. It was pretty symbolic for the way I was (or wasn't) understood by those around me. You don't have to like Joni Mitchell, but do not tell me she sounds awful or that her music doesn't matter. She's done more in her quiet lifetime and had a bigger impact on this world than I will ever have. 

She's my hero, and I will miss her when she's gone.
